Posts.Content: My experience was very similar to Ann.  My tumour was 13mm with no spread to nodes but it turned out to be HER2 positive.  I was given the choice of radiotherapy and tamoxifen only or to add chemotherapy followed by herceptin for a year.  This would bring my chances of recurrence back to if it wasn't HER2 pos but this was a difference of approx 5%.  As I am 42 and with two young sons I took the decision to go for the chemo as I would hate for it to come back without my doing everything possible to stop it. Ann - I have just finished my chemo and like you had moments of wondering if I had done the right thing as I felt I was letting my kids down by lying in bed being completely useless.  I got very down at times but the boys adapted amazingly to my disappearances.  You will get through this. Jules xx
Posts.Title: To Chemo or not to chemo - that is the question?

Posts.Content: This discussion has been really helpful to me.  I will start tamoxifen after Christmas and have been worrying about the side effects.  I have been particularly worried about putting on a lot of weight - vanity really - which is ridiculous since I have coped with my diagnosis, surgery and losing my hair.  Had just got to a weight I was happy with and don't want it to go up again but I suppose its a small price to pay for beating this thing.  Will go with you Jules and try to look on it as a good thing. Jules
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi Jules I will let you know my dosage when I start tamoxifen.  I have heard some horror stories and others have sailed through with hardly any side effects.  I am going to start exercising a lot more once I get stronger - just managing short walks at the moment.  No signs yet of new hair but it is early days.  My problem is that after I shaved my hair very short, not all of it fell out so I have sparse comedy stubble sticking up all over my head about a centimetre long!  But not enough to cover my scalp so I still look bald from a distance and very strange close up!  Can't wait to go out looking "normal" again - I find my wig very uncomfortable so hardly ever wear it. Jules x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi Jules Congratulations on finishing RT! Hope that the Tamoxifen is ok for you - I am still fine on it after 2 months. x Jules
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi Jules I am about to start the tamoxifen today and have 20mg dose once daily.  Am a bit wary of taking the first one! I will let you know how I get on! Jules x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi Jules I've been taking tamoxifen for about 6 weeks now and have only a few side effects. Like Chris I have to pee during the night and didn't before - didn't realise this might be a side effect till I read your post Chris! I am having hot flushes mainly at night (I take my tablet at night) but not too many. I have put on a bit of weight but not sure if its due to tamoxifen cos I lost a lot during chemo so would naturally be putting it back on now.  I do think I have a bit of water retention at times. I am tired but think this is more to do with the after effects of the RT and I started herceptin last week too. So on the whole not as bad as i feared. Jules xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi everyone Well after a few false starts I took my first tamoxifen today!  I completely bottled it last week - and rang my breast nurse in a state so she told me to wait till after the weekend.  I waited till I got to the Hospital for my RT appointment this morning and took it then.  Will keep you posted about side effects.  My oncologist said it was ok to take evening primrose oil supplements so am trying them. I now have the start of very bushy eyebrows!  It looks really odd after having a few hairs on each brow for months.  Will have to start plucking soon!  Eyelashes are also on the way back but quite short still.  I have been using baby shampoo on my head and then massaging it with almond oil - am also quite addicted to this!!  I can definitely see new growth! Jules x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: I think that the side effects of both drugs vary widely from person to person.  I know someone who has switched from Anastrazole to Tamoxifen because she couldn't bear the side effects and is much better on the tamoxifen.  I am one week in with tamoxifen and apart from hot flushes which I was having anyway am ok so far. Jules x
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen It Sounds Awful Is it Really That Bad?

Posts.Content: Hi Fiona My hair started to fall out just over two weeks after first chemo.  It starts with your scalp feeling very tender.  A couple of days later mine was coming out in handfuls.  I shaved it off then cos it was getting everywhere!  I was upset but not as bad as I thought - it felt like taking back some control of my life.  Thinking of you Jules x
Posts.Title: had first chemo Fec what else to come!!!

Posts.Content: I know how shocking it is to expect one set of results and then find that everything has changed.  I was told after surgery that I was very unlikely to need chemotherapy and would just be having radiotherapy and tamoxifen.  On the day I went to sign the consent forms for the radiotherapy I found out that my tumour was HER2 positive and was then offered chemotherapy to be followed by a year of herceptin.  I was in complete shock for days. You will get through this.  Just give yourself time to readjust and to allow your body to heal in its own time.  Don't worry about sitting around in your pjs - I still do that now with very little excuse! Good luck for Tuesday - the waiting for results is often the worst part. Take care Jules xx
Posts.Title: second breast opp and axillery clearance

Posts.Content: Hi Judith Although this is the first time I have posted on this forum, I have been following it for a few months since I was diagnosed in July.  I hope you will find comfort as I have in knowing that you are not alone.  There are so many of us going through this awful experience. I have two young sons, ages 7 and 9 and have shared your fears. The waiting seems to be the worst part. After you know what (if any) treatments you will need after surgery then it gives you something to focus on.   Try not to fear the treatments too much.  I am a complete wimp and I have amazed myself at the strength I have found to get through chemotherapy.   You do have good days as well as challenging ones. Good luck with the surgery. Jules x
